questiontext.text:
Exercise

Considering the line \(L\): \(y=ax+b\).


Changing the value of \(b\) results in a line [[2]].

Changing the value of \(a\) results in a line [[3]].

generalfeedback.text:
The value of \(a\) gives the gradient of the line and changing it has the possibility of making a line perpendicular to \(L\) (can you recall what we would need to change it to?). However this would not be the case for every value. Changing the value of \(a\) will always leave the \(y\)-intercept unchanged since we get this by evaluating at \(x=0\).

In a similar way, if we only change the value of \(b\) then the we change the \(y\)-intercept but not the gradient. We can imagine this as sliding the line up or down the \(y\)-axis and the result will always be parallel to \(L\).
